intro: Lepidium subvaginatum, commonly known as the narrowleaf peppergrass, is a small annual flowering plant native to the western United States and parts of Canada. It belongs to the Brassicaceae family, which includes many economically important crops such as mustard and cabbage. The plant typically grows to a height of 10–30 centimeters and has slender, branching stems covered with small, glandular hairs. Its flowers are small and yellow, arranged in clusters, and it produces small, elongated pods that contain several seeds. Lepidium subvaginatum is often found in disturbed soils and is adapted to arid and semi-arid environments.
